boat.name: Vindilis
boat.full_description:
Harrison Butler was a well-known amateur designer at the time who championed the metacentric theory. He aimed for balance and boats that sailed themselves. When it came to his own boat, he selected the Davinka design and confusingly named her 'Vindilis' (as this was the name of another of his designs).

Moody’s had decided to expand their repair business into yacht building. When he heard this, Harrison Butler placed an order for the first boat.

'Vindilis' is the first Moody. Her sister ship 'Lindy 2' was build number 3 and is also berthed in Emsworth Yacht Harbour. 'Lindy' still has her original rig but the previous owner converted 'Vindilis' to a cutter and she has been left in this form.

Harrison Butler contributed at least two articles to Yachting Monthly in 1935 and 1936. One of these compares the performance of 'Vindilis' with a Bermudan yawl rig against his previous gaffer 'Sandook' (unsurprisingly, faster upwind but downwind the gaffer had the edge). This article reflected much of the debate at the time regarding the new Bermudan. In another article, a cruise through the Naval Review of 1937 is described with battleships moored the length of the Solent.

The previous two owners based 'Vindilis' on the Clyde. She returned to the South Coast for the 2010 season under Richard & Helen Farmer's ownership.
boat.construction_details: Pitch pine planking on oak frames - oak keel and stem teak deck and cabin sides - bronze floors
